Yes, there are several new experiments planned for the LHC in the near future. Here are a few examples:

1. High-Luminosity LHC: This is a major upgrade of the LHC that is planned for the mid-2020s. It will involve building new magnets and increasing the number of collisions that can be produced, which will allow scientists to study rare phenomena that are currently difficult to observe.

2. FCC: The Future Circular Collider (FCC) is a proposed new particle accelerator that would be even larger and more powerful than the LHC. The plan is to build it underneath the existing LHC site and use it to study particle physics, as well as potentially create new particles and explore new physics beyond the Standard Model.

3. Precision studies of the Higgs boson: Scientists are continuing to study the properties of the Higgs boson in more detail, with the goal of understanding its role in the universe and potentially discovering new physics beyond the Standard Model.

4. Dark matter searches: The LHC will continue to search for evidence of dark matter in collisions, using sensitive detectors and advanced analysis techniques to look for any clues that might point to its existence.

Overall, the future of the LHC looks very promising, with many exciting new experiments planned that will further advance our understanding of the universe.
